title: Vertigo / Dizziness Evaluation
scope: ** Evaluation and management of acute vertigo and dizziness in adults. Covers differentiation of peripheral vs. central causes, the HINTS exam, Dix-Hallpike and canalith repositioning maneuvers, evaluation for posterior circulation stroke, and management of common vestibular disorders (BPPV, vestibular neuritis, Meniere's disease, vestibular migraine). Excludes chronic non-specific dizziness (persistent postural-perceptual dizziness), medication-induced dizziness (covered briefly), and presyncope/orthostatic hypotension (separate evaluation).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia can cause dizziness/lightheadedness; hyperglycemia (diabetic neuropathy); metabolic dizziness

Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; anemia (Hgb <10) can cause dizziness; infection markers

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolyte abnormalities (hyponatremia, hypoglycemia); renal dysfunction; dehydration
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; hyponatremia <130 can cause neurologic symptoms including imbalance

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Thyroid dysfunction can cause dizziness/imbalance; hyperthyroidism especially
Cardiac arrhythmia causing presyncope/dizziness; differentiates cardiac from vestibular
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; arrhythmia → cardiac workup; prolonged QTc

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Orthostatic hypotension is common cause of dizziness, especially in elderly; drop in SBP >20 or DBP >10 with symptoms
Essential/Core Labs.target: No orthostatic drop; positive orthostatics → volume status, medication review, autonomic evaluation

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Vascular risk factors if central cause suspected; stroke risk stratification
Diabetes (vascular risk factor; diabetic neuropathy affecting balance)
Neurosyphilis (rare cause of vertigo, especially in HIV); otosyphilis
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; positive → CSF analysis, penicillin treatment

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: B12 deficiency causes peripheral neuropathy and imbalance; subacute combined degeneration
Iron deficiency (even without anemia) can cause dizziness
Autoimmune inner ear disease; vasculitis (CNS vasculitis affecting posterior circulation)
Ototoxic medications (aminoglycosides, salicylates); anticonvulsant toxicity (phenytoin, carbamazepine)
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Therapeutic; toxic levels → adjust or discontinue

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Confirmatory for syphilis if RPR positive; otosyphilis/neurosyphilis
Lyme disease can cause cranial neuropathies, including vestibular neuritis; endemic areas
Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration (anti-Yo, anti-Hu); subacute ataxia with vertigo
If infectious, inflammatory, or neoplastic cause suspected; normal in peripheral vestibular disorders
Familial episodic ataxia; spinocerebellar ataxia; hereditary vestibular disorders
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Specific mutations (CACNA1A for EA2; SCA genes)

Lumbar Puncture.timing: NOT routinely indicated for peripheral vestibular disorders; consider if meningitis, MS, CNS vasculitis, or leptomeningeal disease suspected
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal in BPPV, vestibular neuritis, Meniere's; abnormal → specific CNS pathology

Essential/First-line.item: **HINTS exam (Head Impulse, Nystagmus, Test of Skew)**
Essential/First-line.timing: **CRITICAL bedside exam**; must be performed in patient with ACUTE VESTIBULAR SYNDROME (continuous vertigo, nausea, nystagmus, gait instability); performed by trained examiner; more sensitive than early MRI for stroke
Essential/First-line.target: **Peripheral pattern (benign):** Positive head impulse (catch-up saccade), horizontal nystagmus with unidirectional fast phase, no skew deviation; **Central pattern (concerning for stroke):** Negative/normal head impulse, direction-changing or vertical nystagmus, skew deviation
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Cannot perform if patient not having acute continuous vertigo; requires examiner training

Essential/First-line.timing: **NOT sensitive for posterior fossa stroke** (sensitivity ~20-40%); useful for hemorrhage; may be appropriate for trauma or if MRI not available; does NOT rule out posterior circulation stroke
Essential/First-line.target: Cerebellar or brainstem hemorrhage; mass lesion; hydrocephalus; **NEGATIVE CT does NOT exclude stroke in posterior circulation**

Essential/First-line.timing: **Gold standard for posterior circulation stroke**; DWI highly sensitive for acute ischemia; **HOWEVER:** Early MRI (<48h) can miss 12-20% of small posterior fossa strokes — clinical (HINTS) may be more sensitive; repeat MRI if high suspicion and initial negative
Essential/First-line.target: Acute infarction (restricted diffusion); brainstem lesion; cerebellar lesion; MS plaque; tumor; vestibular schwannoma

Essential/First-line.item: MRA head (CPT 70544) and neck (CPT 70547) (or CTA head (CPT 70496) / neck (CPT 70498))
Essential/First-line.timing: If central cause suspected; vertebral artery dissection; basilar artery stenosis; vertebrobasilar insufficiency
Essential/First-line.target: Vertebral artery dissection; stenosis; occlusion; aneurysm
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRA: same as MRI; CTA: contrast allergy, renal impairment

Extended.timing: **Diagnostic for BPPV** (posterior canal, most common); performed on ALL patients with episodic positional vertigo; positive if nystagmus and vertigo provoked with latency and limited duration
Extended.target: **Positive:** Upbeating-torsional nystagmus toward affected ear, 2-20 sec latency, <60 sec duration, fatigable with repetition = posterior canal BPPV
Extended.contraindications: Cervical spine disease/instability (modify technique); carotid stenosis (theoretical)

Extended.timing: **Diagnostic for horizontal canal BPPV**; patient supine, rapidly turn head 90° to each side; geotropic (toward ground) or apogeotropic (away from ground) horizontal nystagmus
Extended.target: Horizontal nystagmus provoked by head turning; geotropic (canalithiasis) vs. apogeotropic (cupulolithiasis)

Extended.timing: Essential if hearing loss suspected (Meniere's disease, labyrinthitis, vestibular schwannoma); sudden sensorineural hearing loss is emergency
Extended.target: Meniere's: low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss; Schwannoma: asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss; Labyrinthitis: hearing loss + vertigo

Extended.timing: If cardioembolic source suspected for stroke; PFO evaluation; valvular disease
If paroxysmal arrhythmia suspected as cause of dizziness; palpitations with dizziness
Carotid stenosis (though carotid disease rarely causes isolated vertigo without other symptoms)

Rare/Advanced.timing: Quantitative vestibular function testing; caloric testing (ice water or warm/cool air); localizes peripheral lesion; documents vestibular hypofunction
Rare/Advanced.target: Unilateral weakness on calorics (peripheral lesion); central patterns

Rare/Advanced.timing: Quantitative bedside test of vestibulo-ocular reflex; tests individual semicircular canals; more sensitive than bedside HIT
Rare/Advanced.target: Reduced VOR gain; covert/overt saccades; identifies affected canal

Rare/Advanced.timing: Tests saccule (cVEMP) and utricle (oVEMP); superior semicircular canal dehiscence; Meniere's
Rare/Advanced.target: Abnormal in superior canal dehiscence; saccular dysfunction

Rare/Advanced.timing: Quantitative VOR assessment; bilateral vestibular hypofunction
Superior semicircular canal dehiscence; cholesteatoma; temporal bone abnormality
Rare/Advanced.target: Dehiscence of superior canal; bony erosion

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Acute vestibular suppression; first-line for symptomatic vertigo relief

dosing.instructions: start 25 mg PO q8h; may increase to 50 mg q8h for severe vertigo; maximum 72 hours then taper — prolonged use delays vestibular compensation

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Sedation level; limit to 24-72h — chronic use impairs central compensation; reassess if symptoms persist beyond 72h

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Acute vertigo and nausea; alternative vestibular suppressant

dosing.instructions: 50 mg PO or IV every 6 hours; maximum 72 hours then discontinue

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Sedation level; limit to 72h; monitor for anticholinergic effects in elderly

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Acute severe vertigo with nausea; vestibular suppressant with strong antiemetic effect

dosing.instructions: 25 mg every 6 hours; IM preferred over IV (extravasation risk); avoid >72h

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: IV extravasation risk (tissue necrosis); age <2; avoid in elderly (strong anticholinergic)
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Sedation; blood pressure (hypotension risk with IV); limit to 72h

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Nausea and vomiting from acute vertigo; first-line antiemetic

dosing.instructions: 4-8 mg IV/PO every 8 hours; does not suppress vestibular system — safe for ongoing use

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: QTc prolongation >500 ms; concurrent QT-prolonging drugs; serotonin syndrome risk with SSRIs
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: QTc interval; serotonin syndrome symptoms if on serotonergic medications

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Nausea and vomiting from acute vertigo; prokinetic antiemetic

dosing.instructions: 10 mg IV every 6-8 hours; limit to 5 days maximum

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Parkinsonism; tardive dyskinesia risk; GI obstruction; pheochromocytoma; avoid in elderly (EPS risk)
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Extrapyramidal symptoms; limit duration to 5 days; avoid in elderly

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Nausea and vomiting from acute severe vertigo; rescue antiemetic

dosing.instructions: 5-10 mg IV or IM every 6-8 hours; rectal 25 mg suppository alternative

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Parkinsonism; tardive dyskinesia risk; QTc prolongation; dementia (increased mortality)
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Extrapyramidal symptoms; QTc; sedation; blood pressure (hypotension)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Severe acute vertigo refractory to antihistamines; potent vestibular suppressant

dosing.instructions: 2-5 mg PO or IV every 8-12 hours; maximum 72 hours — benzodiazepines strongly delay vestibular compensation

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Respiratory depression; acute angle-closure glaucoma; severe hepatic insufficiency; myasthenia gravis
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Sedation; respiratory status; fall risk; limit to 72h — strongly impairs central vestibular compensation

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Dehydration from vomiting; volume repletion; orthostatic hypotension

dosing.instructions: NS or LR bolus 500-1000 mL; then maintenance as needed; reassess orthostatic vital signs after bolus

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Urine output; orthostatic vital signs; fluid balance

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Rule out posterior circulation stroke in acute vestibular syndrome

dosing.instructions: If ANY central features on HINTS: STAT MRI with DWI; vascular imaging (MRA or CTA); neurology/stroke consultation; central features = normal head impulse test, vertical or direction-changing nystagmus, skew deviation, focal neurologic signs, severe imbalance

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Do not rely on negative CT to exclude posterior fossa stroke
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: HINTS is more sensitive than early CT or MRI for posterior circulation stroke; do NOT discharge if central features present

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: BPPV confirmed by positive Dix-Hallpike; definitive treatment

dosing.instructions: For positive Dix-Hallpike: perform Epley immediately; highly effective (80-90% single treatment); may repeat if symptoms persist; send home with instructions for home Epley or Brandt-Daroff exercises

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Severe cervical spine disease or instability (modify technique); medications are NOT indicated for BPPV
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Symptom resolution; nystagmus resolution; may repeat same session or next visit

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: First-line treatment for posterior canal BPPV; confirmed by positive Dix-Hallpike

dosing.instructions: Patient starts seated → Dix-Hallpike position (30 sec) → rotate head 90° toward opposite side (30 sec) → roll body face down with head still turned (30 sec) → sit up; NNT = 2-3 for resolution

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Severe cervical spine disease or instability; carotid stenosis (theoretical)
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Symptom and nystagmus resolution; may repeat same day or next visit

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Posterior canal BPPV; alternative to Epley

dosing.instructions: Patient moved rapidly from side to side; less commonly used but effective for posterior canal BPPV

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Symptom resolution; use if Epley difficult or ineffective

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Horizontal canal BPPV; geotropic variant

doseOptions.orderSentence: BBQ roll (Lempert maneuver) — horizontal canal N/A positioning

dosing.instructions: Patient rotates 360° along long axis of body (log roll) toward unaffected side; 90° increments with 30 sec pauses between each position
dosing.orderSentence: BBQ roll (Lempert maneuver) — horizontal canal N/A positioning

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Symptom resolution; horizontal nystagmus resolution

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Adjunctive home therapy for residual BPPV symptoms

dosing.instructions: Alternate lying on each side x 30 sec, 10-20 repetitions, 3 times daily; habituates symptoms; less effective than Epley for posterior canal

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Symptom improvement; promotes vestibular compensation

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: After canalith repositioning maneuver

dosing.instructions: Avoid lying flat for 1-2 nights (sleep propped up); avoid rapid head movements for 24-48h; avoid affected side lying for 1 week (controversial but commonly recommended)

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Recurrence of positional symptoms; reduces immediate recurrence

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Vestibular neuritis; start within 72h of symptom onset for best benefit

dosing.instructions: 1 mg/kg/day (max 60 mg) x 10 days then taper over 5 days; [Strupp et al. (2004)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15269315/) — NNT ~4 for complete vestibular recovery

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Active infection (relative); uncontrolled diabetes; GI bleeding
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Glucose (hyperglycemia); blood pressure; GI symptoms; psychiatric side effects; insomnia

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Vestibular neuritis; severe cases or unable to take PO

dosing.instructions: 100 mg IV daily x 3 days then transition to oral prednisone taper

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Glucose; blood pressure; psychiatric side effects

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Vestibular neuritis; empiric antiviral if early presentation

dosing.instructions: Evidence is WEAK; Cochrane review shows no clear benefit; some clinicians use empirically, especially if labyrinthitis with hearing loss (HSV reactivation theory)

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Renal function; limited evidence of benefit

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Vestibular neuritis/labyrinthitis; short-term symptom relief

dosing.instructions: 25 mg q8h; taper off as soon as tolerated; STOP after 72 hours maximum — prolonged use delays vestibular compensation

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Sedation; MUST discontinue by 72h to allow central compensation

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Vestibular neuritis/labyrinthitis; START EARLY after acute symptoms controlled

dosing.instructions: Refer to vestibular physical therapy; gaze stabilization exercises; balance training; habituation exercises; Cochrane review confirms efficacy for unilateral vestibular hypofunction

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Functional improvement; balance assessment; early initiation improves outcomes

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: First-line lifestyle modification for Meniere's; reduces endolymphatic hydrops

dosing.instructions: Sodium <1500-2000 mg/day; limit caffeine and alcohol; regular meals; avoid MSG

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Attack frequency; dietary compliance; evidence limited but widely recommended

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Meniere's disease; reduces endolymph volume

dosing.instructions: 25-50 mg daily; alternative: HCTZ/triamterene (Dyazide) to reduce potassium wasting

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Sulfa allergy; severe renal impairment; hypokalemia
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Potassium; renal function; blood pressure; widely used despite limited RCT evidence

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Meniere's disease; alternative diuretic

dosing.instructions: 250 mg BID; carbonic anhydrase inhibitor

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Sulfa allergy; severe hepatic disease; hyponatremia
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Electrolytes (metabolic acidosis); renal function; paresthesias

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Meniere's disease; H1 agonist/H3 antagonist improving cochlear blood flow

dosing.instructions: 16-24 mg TID; not available in US; available in Europe and Canada; evidence mixed; may reduce attack frequency

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Attack frequency; hearing; GI symptoms

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Refractory Meniere's disease; less destructive than gentamicin

dosing.instructions: Dexamethasone intratympanic injection; preserves hearing; less consistent efficacy than gentamicin

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Middle ear infection; tympanic membrane perforation
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Hearing (audiometry); vertigo frequency; alternative to gentamicin

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Refractory unilateral Meniere's disease; chemical vestibular ablation

dosing.instructions: Destroys vestibular hair cells; reduces vertigo attacks; effective >80%; risk of hearing loss 10-30%

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Bilateral Meniere's (risk of bilateral vestibular loss); only hearing ear
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Hearing (audiometry before and after); balance function; reserved for refractory cases

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Refractory Meniere's disease; surgical option

dosing.instructions: Surgical decompression of endolymphatic sac; Cochrane review shows limited evidence; considered for refractory cases

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Hearing; vertigo frequency; controversial efficacy

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Refractory unilateral Meniere's disease; last resort

doseOptions.orderSentence: Vestibular nerve section / Labyrinthectomy N/A surgical

dosing.instructions: Nerve section preserves hearing; labyrinthectomy destroys hearing; both highly effective for vertigo control
dosing.orderSentence: Vestibular nerve section / Labyrinthectomy N/A surgical

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Hearing; balance; vestibular rehabilitation post-op; significant surgery — last resort

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Acute vestibular migraine attack; abortive therapy

dosing.instructions: 50-100 mg PO; or 6 mg SC for severe attacks; may repeat x1 after 2 hours (PO)

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Coronary artery disease; uncontrolled hypertension; hemiplegic migraine; basilar migraine; concurrent ergots or MAO-Is
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Chest symptoms; cardiovascular risk; headache frequency (limit to <10 days/month to avoid MOH)

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Vestibular migraine prophylaxis; first-line preventive

dosing.instructions: 40-160 mg daily; titrate over 2-4 weeks; preferred if concurrent hypertension

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Asthma; severe bradycardia; heart block; decompensated HF; diabetes (masks hypoglycemia)
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Heart rate; blood pressure; depression symptoms; exercise tolerance

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Vestibular migraine prophylaxis; preferred if concurrent insomnia or depression

dosing.instructions: 10-75 mg at bedtime; titrate by 10 mg every 1-2 weeks; anticholinergic effects limit use in elderly

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Glaucoma; urinary retention; recent MI; concurrent MAO-Is; QTc prolongation
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Weight; anticholinergic side effects; ECG if dose >50 mg; somnolence

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Vestibular migraine prophylaxis; alternative preventive

dosing.instructions: start 25 mg daily, titrate to 50-100 mg BID over 4-8 weeks; weight-neutral to weight-loss effect

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Bicarbonate (metabolic acidosis); renal function; cognitive side effects; weight

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Vestibular migraine prophylaxis; preferred if concurrent anxiety or depression

dosing.instructions: 37.5-150 mg daily; titrate by 37.5 mg every 1-2 weeks

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Uncontrolled hypertension; concurrent MAO-Is; abrupt discontinuation (withdrawal)
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Blood pressure (dose-dependent hypertension); mood; discontinuation must be gradual

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Chronic vestibular symptoms between migraine attacks

dosing.instructions: Balance training; habituation exercises; helpful for interictal vestibular symptoms and disability

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Functional improvement; symptom frequency

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Acute posterior circulation stroke within thrombolysis window

doseOptions.orderSentence: IV alteplase (tPA) or tenecteplase N/A IV

dosing.instructions: Per acute ischemic stroke protocol; consider IV thrombolysis if within window; endovascular therapy for basilar artery occlusion
dosing.orderSentence: IV alteplase (tPA) or tenecteplase N/A IV

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Standard tPA contraindications (see acute ischemic stroke plan)
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Posterior circulation stroke is life-threatening; basilar artery occlusion has >80% mortality if untreated; neuro checks q15 min

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Acute posterior circulation stroke; if not tPA candidate

dosing.instructions: 325 mg loading dose within 24-48h (if not receiving tPA); then dual antiplatelet per CHANCE/POINT trial

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Active GI bleeding; aspirin allergy; within 24h of tPA
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: GI bleeding; platelet function

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Secondary stroke prevention; minor stroke or TIA

doseOptions.orderSentence: Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) 325/75 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Aspirin 325 mg + clopidogrel 75 mg x 21 days per CHANCE/POINT trial; then single agent
dosing.orderSentence: Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) 325/75 mg PO

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Bleeding; platelet function; duration 21 days then reassess

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Secondary stroke prevention; vascular risk reduction

dosing.instructions: High-intensity statin per guidelines

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Active liver disease; pregnancy; concurrent strong CYP3A4 inhibitors
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: LFTs at baseline and PRN; CK if myalgia; LDL target <70

Disease-Specific Treatment.indication: Vertebral artery dissection; atrial fibrillation; PFO with high-risk features

dosing.instructions: Agent selection based on stroke etiology: heparin bridge to warfarin or DOAC for AF; anticoagulation vs. antiplatelet for dissection per clinical judgment

Disease-Specific Treatment.contraindications: Active intracranial hemorrhage; large infarct (hemorrhagic conversion risk)
Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: INR (warfarin); renal function (DOACs); bleeding signs; stroke etiology determines agent

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Meclizine, dimenhydrinate, promethazine, scopolamine — chronic use

dosing.instructions: Vestibular suppressants delay central compensation; limit to 72h maximum in acute vertigo; do NOT prescribe chronically; NEVER for BPPV

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Prolonged use leads to chronic imbalance and delayed recovery; taper and discontinue by day 3

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Diazepam, lorazepam, clonazepam — chronic vestibular use

dosing.instructions: Benzodiazepines strongly suppress vestibular compensation; acceptable for 24-72h acute use only; chronic use causes dependence, cognitive impairment, fall risk

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Taper if already on chronic benzodiazepines; refer to vestibular rehabilitation instead

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Aminoglycosides (gentamicin, tobramycin); loop diuretics (furosemide); high-dose salicylates; cisplatin

dosing.instructions: Can cause or worsen vestibular dysfunction and hearing loss; if must use, monitor levels closely; aminoglycosides preferentially damage vestibular apparatus

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.contraindications: Use alternative antibiotics when possible; monitor drug levels
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Audiometry; vestibular function; drug levels (aminoglycosides); hearing symptoms

dosing.instructions: Orthostatic dizziness mimics vestibular vertigo; review all medications that lower blood pressure; dose-adjust or change timing

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Orthostatic vital signs; medication reconciliation; consider dose reduction

dosing.instructions: Alcohol is directly vestibulotoxic (positional alcohol nystagmus); impairs vestibular compensation; exacerbates Meniere's disease

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Counsel abstinence during acute vestibular recovery; limit in Meniere's disease

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Opioids, sedative-hypnotics, muscle relaxants, first-generation antihistamines

dosing.instructions: CNS depressants impair vestibular compensation; increase fall risk; can worsen dizziness symptoms; minimize use during vestibular recovery

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Fall risk assessment; minimize concurrent CNS depressant use; prefer non-sedating alternatives

Orthostatic hypotension, cardiac arrhythmia, vasovagal syncope, dehydration

differential.tests: Peripheral neuropathy, cerebellar disorders, bilateral vestibular loss, Parkinson's disease, cervical spondylosis
Anxiety/panic disorder, depression, hyperventilation, medication side effects, PPPD
Sudden or gradual

Positive (eyes at different heights; covered eye moves when uncovered)

evidence.evidenceLevel: HINTS exam (H: head impulse; I: nystagmus; TS: test of skew) was 100% sensitive and 96% specific for stroke in acute vestibular syndrome; superior to MRI in first 24-48h
evidence.source: HINTS should be performed in acute vestibular syndrome; more sensitive than early MRI

evidence.evidenceLevel: Methylprednisolone improved vestibular function recovery in vestibular neuritis vs. placebo
evidence.source: Steroids are standard of care for vestibular neuritis

evidence.evidenceLevel: Epley maneuver highly effective for posterior canal BPPV; NNT ~3
evidence.source: Epley is definitive treatment for BPPV

evidence.evidenceLevel: Individual HINTS components analyzed; normal head impulse most predictive of stroke
evidence.source: "Dangerous" HIT (normal in acute vertigo) = central cause until proven otherwise

evidence.evidenceLevel: 12-20% of posterior fossa strokes missed on early MRI (<48h) but detected on repeat MRI
evidence.source: If high clinical suspicion for stroke and initial MRI negative, repeat MRI or treat as stroke

evidence.evidenceLevel: Comprehensive BPPV guideline; repositioning maneuvers recommended; vestibular suppressants NOT recommended

monitoring.frequency: On presentation; q1-2h if central concern
monitoring.action: Central features → STAT MRI; neurology/stroke consultation
IV fluids if dehydrated from vomiting
PT evaluation; fall precautions; walker if needed
Persistent: repeat evaluation; vestibular rehab; subspecialty referral
Worsening: urgent ENT referral; MRI for schwannoma
Repeat Epley; home exercises; canal switch (rare)

disposition.criteria: Confirmed or highly suspected posterior circulation stroke; basilar artery occlusion; cerebellar stroke with mass effect/hydrocephalus
Intractable vomiting/dehydration requiring IV fluids and monitoring; diagnostic uncertainty requiring observation and further testing; elderly with high fall risk and no safe home environment
Prolonged symptoms requiring IV fluids and antiemetics; need for serial neurologic exams; MRI pending
BPPV (treated with Epley); vestibular neuritis/labyrinthitis (steroids started, symptoms manageable); Meniere's (acute episode resolved)
HINTS peripheral pattern; OR MRI negative (with appropriate follow-up if early MRI); no focal neurologic deficits
Nausea/vomiting controlled; able to tolerate PO
Can walk safely (with or without assistance); low fall risk; or adequate home support
Diagnosis explained; treatment plan; when to return (new neurologic symptoms, worsening vertigo, hearing loss)
PCP within 1 week; neurology/ENT if indicated; vestibular PT if indicated
